quote_a: My most common use for AI would be in the garden. What I do is use ChatGPT specifically to set up an annual flow of the tasks that I need to do in my garden. I ask what kind of work I can do in winter, what I should be doing in spring, summer, and autumn. I use it to estimate how long that work would take, set times for growth, match the plants I have with companion plants that will grow well together, and help me diagnose issues with my trees.
quote_b: I think it comes down to surface-level issues. AI specifically can't relate to certain things that I'm speaking about, like being forgetful or the gardening topics, where a human would be able to engage more deeply. A human might say, "Oh, has this happened? Have you seen...?" There's just a deeper level of conversation between humans than between a human and an AI.
explanation: The participant describes gardening as their most common AI use case and relies on it heavily for garden planning, yet later claims AI specifically cannot relate to gardening topics â€” opposing sentiments about AI's utility in the same domain.
